channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Lede: Video Broadcast on State Television Was Downloaded From U.S. Drone, Iran Says
item.description: Iran's state television showed what it described as video recorded by the American surveillance drone that crash-landed about 140 miles from the country's border with Afghanistan in late 2011.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: At War Blog: U.S. and Allies Conduct Drills in Persian Gulf, a Signal to Iran
item.description: The exercise included a simulation to test the policy-making and coordination of the American military and two dozen other nations, as well as drills at sea, in the air and on land.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER

item.title: The Lede: Egyptian Prime Minister Criticized for Soliloquy on 'Ignorant' Mothers
item.description: In the middle of political turmoil, Egypt's prime minister, Hisham Qandil, took a moment to blame infant diarrhea on the unclean breasts of "ignorant" nursing mothers.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK
item.media:description: Women present for the Egyptian prime minister's remarks blaming "ignorant" mothers' unclean breasts for diarrhea in nursing infants appeared confused and uncomfortable.

item.title: Senate Panel Examines Benghazi Attack
item.description: The remarks by Gen. Martin E. Dempsey came at an appearance with Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta, about an attack in Libya that killed Americans.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta, left, and Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, appeared before the Senate Armed Services Committee on Thursday.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: Feb. 7
item.description: A snow covered field in Gulmarg, Jammu and Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Stark Numbers Reveal the Scale of Elephant Killings
item.description: The stream of news about elephant killings and increasingly massive ivory seizures has been so relentless that it has become numbing. A new study, however, still has the power to shock.
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER
item.media:description: Elephant tusks seized by customs officials in Hong Kong in January.

item.title: Lens Blog: Sirkka-Liisa Konttinen's Photos of Her Newcastle Neighborhood
item.description: Sirkka-Liisa Konttinen, a Finnish photographer, began taking pictures of her new neighborhood in Newcastle, in northeast England, in 1969, having no idea the area was slated for demolition.
item.category: UNESCO UK Memory of the World
item.dc:creator: By MATT MCCANN

item.title: India Ink: Economic Growth in India to Fall to 5 Percent
item.description: Sluggish performance in manufacturing, agriculture and services contributed to the drop.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI

item.title: Way of the World: Theorizing About Taxing High Earners
item.description: Among economists who study the surge in pay at the top of the income pyramid, it is pretty much a truth universally acknowledged that taxes should rise at the summit, too.
item.dc:creator: By CHRYSTIA FREELAND | REUTERS

item.title: India Ink: Child Sexual Abuse Rampant and Untreated in India, Report Says
item.description: The response by the police and the government when children do report abuses often adds more trauma, the report by Human Rights Watch said.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By HEATHER TIMMONS

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: In Worldwide Soccer Corruption Scandal, an Asian Tie
item.description: The reputation of soccer, beloved of many, has been seriously tarnished by a report of massive match-fixing that includes top European games, with the epicenter of the trouble in Asia, investigators said.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Singapore defenders, in red, try to block an attempt at goal by a player from the Philippines during an Asean Football Federation match in 2012 in Manila. Singapore and the Philippines have been named by investigators as centers of illegal soccer gambling and match fixing.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Baron Von Fancy Goes to Paris
item.description: The artist and fashion designer Baron Von Fancy's name may belong in an 18th-century German royal court, but he owes his budding career to Instagram.
item.dc:creator: By HANNAH OLIVENNES
item.media:description: Baron Von Fancy mural behind the register at the Colette store in Paris.

item.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader, Ayatollah Ali Khameini, Rejects Direct Talks With U.S.
item.description: Other Iranian officials were open to bilateral talks on a range of issues, including Iran’s disputed nuclear program, but the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khameini, has the last word.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Calling Henry Higgins: School Makes a Case for Standard English
item.description: As one British school seeks to boost the use of the Queen's English, local traditionalists grumble that proud regional dialects are under threat. In an increasingly standardized world, should we all learn to speak the same way?
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS

item.title: Court Urged to Reverse a Ruling on Terror
item.description: The Obama administration on Wednesday urged a federal appeals court to overturn a ruling that blocked enforcement of a statute related to the indefinite detention without trial of terrorism suspects.
item.dc:creator: By COLIN MOYNIHAN

item.title: New Political Uncertainty Grips Tunisia After Assassination
item.description: A day after a leading opposition figure was assassinated outside his home, Tunisia’s dominant party said it opposed a plan to dissolve the government, according to news reports.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MONICA MARKS, KAREEM FAHIM and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: People placed flowers at the site outside his home where opposition leader Chokri Belaid was killed the day before on Thursday in Tunis.

item.title: I.H.T. Special: Social Media Firms Move to Capitalize on Popularity in Middle East
item.description: The rise of social media in the Arab world is changing the game for regional advertisers, pushing growth in digital advertising.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SARA HAMDAN
item.media:description: Egyptian protesters look at Facebook during a demonstration in Cairo on January 14.

item.title: At War Blog: Interview With Gen. John R. Allen on Leaving Afghanistan
item.description: The New York Times interviewed Gen. John. R. Allen on Sunday, a week before his scheduled departure from Afghanistan after 19 months as the commander of the American and allied forces.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: Lashkar-e-Taiba Founder Takes Less Militant Tone in Pakistan
item.description: The United States has offered $10 million for help convicting Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, the Pakistani founder of the group behind the 2008 attacks in Mumbai, India.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I move about like an ordinary person — that’s my style,” said Hafiz Muhammad Saeed. “My fate is in the hands of God, not America.”

item.title: India Ink: Five Questions for: Author Tahar Ben Jelloun
item.description: The French author on his latest book and his occupational hazards.
item.dc:creator: By PAMPOSH RAINA

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: 'Rigoletto' in Vegas, 'Manon Lescaut' in the Metro
item.description: Sometimes updating an opera's setting works; sometimes it doesn't.
item.dc:creator: By GEORGE LOOMIS
item.media:description: The new production of the Puccini opera "Manon Lescaut" at La Monnaie in Brussels.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: Feb. 7
item.description: Protests in Tunisia after an opposition leader is killed; an overhaul of European fisheries; a crossroads for the Galileo navigation system; and the Sri Lankan women's cricket team stuns India.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: Tunisian protesters clashed with the riot police during a demonstration after the death of Mr. Belaid outside the Interior ministry in Tunis on Wednesday.

item.title: Clashes Erupt in Damascus as Prospects for Syrian Talks Dim
item.description: Some antigovernment activists described the fighting in Syria as part of a renewed effort by rebels to seize control of central Damascus, but that claim appeared to be exaggerated.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By HANIA MOURTADA and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A man stood near a building that was hit by a mortar shell in a neighborhood of Damascus on Wednesday, when an outbreak of fighting there shattered a lull.

item.title: Hagel Wouldn’t Be First Enlisted Man as Pentagon Chief
item.description: President Obama, in nominating Chuck Hagel, said he would be the “first person of enlisted rank” to run the Pentagon, but at least four defense secretaries were, too.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH BUMILLER
item.media:description: Four secretaries of defense served as enlisted men before being promoted. Chuck Hagel, left, would be the only Pentagon chief to have served his entire military career as an enlisted man.

item.title: India Ink: Sri Lanka Shakes Up Women's Cricket World Cup
item.description: Sri Lanka will take part in the Super Six playoffs starting Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
